newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: RUGBY LEAGUE-MURDOCH PROMISES SUPER LEAGUE NEXT YEAR.
newsitem.headline: RUGBY LEAGUE-MURDOCH PROMISES SUPER LEAGUE NEXT YEAR.

text.p: Media baron Rupert Murdoch said on
Friday he would launch his rebel Super League in Australia next
year after winning a stunning legal victory over rugby league's
established order.
Murdoch was freed to start his breakaway league when
Australia's Federal Court overturned an earlier ruling banning
his competition from kicking off here before the year 2000.
Britain, a Super League ally, immediately moved to organise
an international fixture later this month against an Australian
side featuring players under contract to Murdoch.
Murdoch himself promised to transform a sport that is coming
increasingly under his control around the world.
"Super League represents a new dimension in international
sport and 1997 will see the finest rugby league competition ever
created," he said in a statement issued in Los Angeles.
The legal victory, immediately freeing eight existing clubs
and more than 200 players to defect to Super League, means there
will almost certainly be two rival leagues in Australia in 1997.
But it does not spell the end of a bitter, protracted power
struggle with the Australian Rugby League (ARL), the established
domestic ruling body which runs an existing competition.
Several hours after the court ruling, ARL chairman Ken
Arthurson said his organisation would seek leave to appeal the
decision in Australia's highest court.
Murdoch thanked the players and clubs who he said had stood
by him during the battle.
"They have never lost faith in our belief in what rugby
league could and should become: a truly international sport," he
said. Murdoch has already invested A$270 million (US$213
million) in Super League.
The eight clubs now free to join Super League are Brisbane
Broncos, Canberra Raiders, Cronulla Sharks, Auckland Warriors,
Western Reds, Sydney Bulldogs, North Queensland and Penrith.
A host of prominent international players are also
contracted to Super League, including former test scrumhalf
Ricky Stuart and backs Laurie Daley and Andrew Ettingshausen.
English Rugby Football League chief executive Maurice
Lindsay said he wanted wanted to add the match against
Australia's Super League side to Britain's current South Pacific
tour.
"We are going to discuss the matter with our Australian
colleagues and try and find a venue and a date in October to
have an inaugural game between Great Britain and Australia Super
League," Lindsay said from London in an interview on Australian
Broadcasting Corporation radio.
Britain and New Zealand, the two major rugby league playing
nation alongside outside Australia, joined the Super League camp
in early 1995, several months after Murdoch's plans first became
public. Murdoch's BSkyB satellite and cable television already
screens the European version of the Super League.
